alt_statements.statement: I think we should protect nature first, because God made the earth and we’re supposed to take care of it, but adults should still find smart ways for people to have jobs and make money without hurting the planet so much. Grown-ups should invent cleaner machines and energy so businesses can keep going, but they should have rules so they don’t pollute the air and make the weather worse for kids like me when we grow up.

I think protecting the environment should come first, because this is the only planet we have and my generation has to live with the consequences. But I also know people need jobs and money to support their families, so I think we should focus on creating new kinds of work that are good for the earth, like clean energy and greener technology. If we make fair rules that help both nature and people, then we don’t have to choose between a healthy planet and a good life.

As someone who worked in healthcare and now lives simply on almost nothing, I’ve seen how environmental damage and extreme weather hit everyday people first, especially those without a safety net. We shouldn’t pretend it’s a choice between jobs and the planet—good climate policy should create new, decent-paying work in clean energy and infrastructure while phasing out the worst polluters. I’d rather see us invest in protecting our air, water, and climate now than pay the price later in medical bills, disasters, and lost communities. Economic growth that destroys our environment isn’t real progress; it needs to be measured by how well it protects people and the places we call home.

As someone who works a physical job and lives on a modest income, I know how important it is that climate policies don’t just sound good on paper but actually protect both the planet and people like me who can’t afford higher costs or lost jobs. I think we should push hard on clean energy, public transit, and green jobs so we’re cutting emissions while creating better-paying, safer work, especially in working-class and Black communities that feel pollution the most. Environmental protection has to come first because there’s no economy on a dying planet, but the transition has to be fair, with support like job training, affordable energy, and healthcare so regular folks aren’t left behind.

Como mujer que trabaja duro en un supermercado y que ha tenido que empezar de nuevo en este país, creo que cuidar el medioambiente es muy importante, pero no se puede hacer de una forma que deje a la gente sin trabajo o que suba demasiado el costo de la vida. Las políticas sobre el clima deben ser prácticas, graduales y enfocadas en soluciones que también ayuden a la economía, como apoyar a las pequeñas empresas, mejorar el transporte público y promover energías más limpias sin castigar a los que menos tenemos.

As someone who delivers packages for a living and supports a family, I know how important a strong economy and steady work are—but I also see how extreme weather and pollution can hurt our communities, especially working-class and immigrant neighborhoods. Climate policy should push companies and governments to invest in cleaner technology and infrastructure in a way that protects jobs and helps workers transition, not just raises costs for regular people. We shouldn’t have to pick between good jobs and a healthy planet; with the right incentives and support, we can have both and make sure everyone has a fair shot in the new green economy.

Working in healthcare, I see how environmental conditions directly affect people’s health, so I think climate policy has to prioritize protecting our air, water, and long‑term wellbeing, even if that means some short‑term economic tradeoffs. That said, I don’t believe it’s an either/or choice: with smart planning and investment, we can create good jobs in cleaner industries while phasing out the most harmful practices. Economic growth that undermines public health and damages communities isn’t real progress, but growth that respects environmental limits can be both sustainable and beneficial.

As a medical research scientist, I see climate policy first and foremost as a public health intervention: environmental degradation directly drives disease, strain on healthcare systems, and long‑term economic instability. Economic growth that depends on high emissions is, biologically speaking, a short‑lived gain with severe downstream costs, so our priority should be aggressive emissions reductions and ecosystem protection, paired with targeted investment in green industries and worker retraining. In other words, we shouldn’t be trading health for GDP; we should be redefining growth so that clean energy, resilient infrastructure, and low‑carbon innovation are the engines of a healthier, more sustainable economy.

At my age, I’ve seen what happens when we put short-term profits ahead of the world we leave our children, and it isn’t pretty. Climate policy should put environmental protection first, with economic growth reshaped around clean energy, conservation, and green jobs rather than fossil fuels and waste. We’re creative enough as a society to build an economy that thrives without destroying creation, and government has a moral responsibility—one I see as deeply Catholic—to protect the most vulnerable people and ecosystems from climate harm.

As someone who works in aircraft manufacturing, I see firsthand how important a strong economy and good jobs are for families like mine, but I also spend a lot of time outdoors and feel a responsibility to protect the natural world my kids will grow up in. I think climate policy should push innovation—cleaner technologies, more efficient designs, and smarter regulations—so we reduce emissions without gutting industries or putting people out of work. Instead of treating environmental protection and economic growth as opposites, we should see them as partners, using market incentives and clear rules to drive long-term, sustainable prosperity. That approach respects both personal freedom and our duty to be good stewards of God’s creation.

As a father and a provider with a stressful job tied to national security, I think climate policy has to protect the environment in a way that doesn’t cripple our economy or jeopardize American energy independence. We should invest in cleaner technologies and practical regulations, but always with an eye on jobs, cost of living, and keeping the U.S. from relying on foreign energy sources. Environmental goals need to be met through innovation, market incentives, and gradual transitions—not heavy-handed mandates that hit working families and businesses the hardest.

I think we need a practical balance where we protect the environment without wrecking people’s livelihoods, especially in service industries like the one I work in. Smart climate policy should push businesses toward cleaner energy and less waste, but in a gradual, predictable way so companies can plan, keep people employed, and keep prices reasonable. As a moderate and a Catholic, I see caring for creation and being responsible stewards as important, but so is making sure working families and small businesses aren’t crushed by sudden costs.

At my age, I’ve seen what happens when we put short-term profits ahead of long-term stewardship, and I firmly believe environmental protection has to come first, with economic growth reshaped to fit within those limits. We are clever enough as a society to create good jobs in clean energy, conservation, and climate-resilient infrastructure, so “growth” doesn’t have to mean poisoning our air and water. As a person of faith, I see caring for creation as a moral obligation, and as a Democrat I support strong regulations and investments that help workers and communities transition fairly to a greener economy.

I think we need to protect God’s creation, but we also can’t forget that folks need steady jobs and affordable gas and electricity to support their families. Climate policy should focus on practical, common-sense steps—like encouraging cleaner but reliable energy, improving efficiency in trucks and logistics, and promoting innovation—without piling on regulations that crush small businesses or drive up costs.

I think we need a balance where we protect the environment without destroying people’s jobs and paychecks. Climate rules should push companies to be cleaner and more efficient, but they shouldn’t be so extreme that factories shut down or move overseas. I’d rather see practical steps like better technology, incentives for cleaner production, and gradual changes than big, sudden mandates that hit working families first.

I believe we need a climate policy that protects our land, air, and water without strangling the jobs and industries that keep families like mine afloat. We should invest in cleaner, more efficient technologies and common‑sense regulations that cut waste and pollution, but changes need to be gradual and practical so energy costs don’t skyrocket and working folks aren’t left behind. Environmental protection matters, but it has to go hand in hand with strong economic growth, not be pitted against it.

I believe we need to be good stewards of God’s creation, but we also have to be realistic and protect people’s jobs and pocketbooks, especially those of us on fixed incomes. Climate policies should focus on practical, affordable steps—like encouraging cleaner technology and conservation—without crippling small businesses or raising energy bills so high that ordinary folks can’t keep up.

As a teacher and a mom, I see environmental protection and economic growth as deeply connected, not competing goals. We should prioritize strong climate policies that transition us to clean energy and sustainable practices, while investing in green jobs and retraining so working families and local communities aren’t left behind. In the long run, a healthy environment is the foundation of a stable economy, and we owe it to our kids to make decisions that protect their future, not just next quarter’s numbers.

Working in veterinary care, I see firsthand how environmental damage translates into real suffering for animals, so I think climate policy has to prioritize environmental protection even if it means reshaping how we do business. Long-term economic health depends on a stable climate and functioning ecosystems, so framing it as “environment vs. economy” is misleading—we should be investing in green jobs, renewable energy, and sustainable agriculture that protect both livelihoods and the living world.

I think protecting the environment should come first, because if the planet gets too messed up, there won’t be a safe future for kids like me no matter how much money people make. But I also get that families need jobs and businesses need to keep running, so I think we should invest in clean energy and green jobs that help the economy grow without destroying nature.

I think we’ve got to be smart about climate policy so it protects the land and air we all depend on, without crushing the folks who actually keep the economy moving. As a truck driver, I see how regulations can pile up costs on working people, so I’d rather see incentives for cleaner technology and practical standards than heavy-handed rules from Washington. We should push for innovation—more efficient trucks, better fuels, smarter logistics—so businesses can grow and jobs stay strong while we still take care of God’s creation.

As someone who works with cars and needs to support my kids, I think climate policy has to protect both our environment and our paychecks. We should push for cleaner technologies and stricter standards, but in a way that doesn’t suddenly make it impossible for regular working families to afford a car or keep a steady job. I’d rather see gradual changes, support for workers to retrain or upgrade skills, and incentives for businesses to go green instead of just heavy-handed rules. Taking care of God’s creation matters, but so does making sure people can still provide for their families.

At my age, I’ve seen how chasing short-term economic gains without regard for the environment always seems to leave ordinary people paying the price later. I believe climate policy should put environmental protection first, with smart, steady investments in clean energy and infrastructure that also create good jobs and help communities—especially those with fewer resources—transition fairly. Economic growth that destroys the planet we leave to our grandchildren isn’t really “growth” at all; it’s a debt we’re passing on.

As someone who’s built a livelihood running a small consulting business, I believe climate policy has to protect our environment without crippling the economy or punishing job creators. We should focus on practical, market-based solutions and incentives for innovation—especially in American industry—rather than heavy-handed regulations that drive costs up for families and small businesses. Protecting the earth is part of our duty as stewards of God’s creation, but that stewardship should respect people’s need to work, invest, and grow. A balanced approach means gradual, realistic targets and policies that keep the U.S. competitive while encouraging cleaner, more efficient technologies.

At my age, I’ve seen what happens when companies and politicians ignore the environment, and we can’t keep kicking that can down the road just to squeeze out a little more profit. We need strong climate policies that push businesses toward cleaner technologies and energy, with support to help workers and small companies transition so people don’t get left behind. Protecting the environment and growing the economy isn’t an either-or thing anymore; long-term economic health depends on having clean air, stable weather, and a livable planet for the next generation.

I think we need a climate policy that protects our land, air, and water without strangling the very jobs and industries that keep families like mine afloat. We should push for practical solutions—like cleaner technology, better fuel standards, and incentives for efficiency—rather than heavy-handed regulations that drive up costs and shut down small businesses. America can lead on the environment while still building things, making things, and keeping our energy reliable and affordable.

My mommy and daddy tell me we have to take care of the air and trees so I can keep playing outside and be healthy, so I think that’s really important. I don’t understand money or jobs yet, but if people make things and build things, they should do it in a way that doesn’t make the sky dirty or hurt animals.

As a young dad working in a pretty physical job, I want my kids to grow up in a world with clean air and a stable climate, but I also need policies that don’t wipe out working-class jobs or jack up our basic costs overnight. I think we should push hard on clean energy and efficiency, with strong environmental standards, but pair that with serious investment in retraining, good union jobs, and support for communities that depend on old industries. Environmental protection should set the direction, and economic growth should come from building the new green economy in a way that doesn’t leave regular families behind.

We need a balanced approach where we protect God’s creation and our communities without crippling the jobs and local economies families depend on. Climate policy should focus on practical, cost‑effective solutions—like improving energy efficiency, expanding clean natural gas and nuclear, and encouraging innovation in private industry—rather than heavy-handed regulations that punish small businesses and working people. Environmental rules should be based on solid evidence, clear benefits, and respect for states’ rights, so we can keep our air and water clean while still allowing American workers and companies to stay competitive.

At my age, I’ve seen what happens when we put short-term profit ahead of the places we call home, and I don’t want my grandchildren’s generation inheriting a damaged planet because we were afraid to change. Climate policy should put environmental protection first, with economic growth redefined around clean energy, sustainable jobs, and caring for the communities and workers who have to transition away from fossil fuels. We’re a wealthy country and we have the creativity and resources to do both, but when there’s a conflict, the health of the Earth and ordinary people—not corporate earnings—ought to win.

As a physician, I see every day how health is inseparable from the environment we live in—air quality, heat, and pollution all show up in my patients’ charts—so I can’t accept the idea that economic growth should come at the cost of a livable planet. My faith and humanitarian values push me toward policies that aggressively reduce emissions and protect vulnerable communities, while still supporting innovation, green jobs, and just transitions for workers. We should treat environmental protection as a non‑negotiable foundation and design our economy around it, not the other way around.

As a young Navajo mom who’s still in school and trying to make ends meet, I don’t see environmental protection and economic growth as opposites—we need both, but the planet has to set the limits. Climate policy should protect the land, air, and water first, because without those there is no real economy, and at the same time invest in clean energy jobs, better schools, and infrastructure so families like mine in New Mexico can have real opportunities.

As someone who works in a restaurant and is raising kids on a tight budget, I don’t think we should have to choose between protecting the environment and having enough jobs and affordable food—climate policy has to do both. We need strong rules that push companies to cut pollution and invest in clean energy, but those same policies should make sure working families get support, like lower utility bills, better public transit, and new good-paying jobs in greener industries. Climate change already hits poorer communities and immigrants like mine the hardest, so real economic growth for me means cleaner air, safer neighborhoods, and opportunities for our children, not just higher profits for big corporations.

As someone who works in education, makes a good living, and spends much of my free time outdoors with my family, I don’t see environmental protection and economic growth as opposing goals, but I do think environmental limits have to come first. If we degrade the ecosystems we depend on, any short-term economic gains are meaningless, and our kids will pay the price. Climate policy should set strong, science-based regulations and invest heavily in clean energy and conservation, while helping workers and communities transition so that a sustainable economy becomes the foundation for long-term prosperity.

As someone working in telecommunications, I see every day how a strong economy and new technology can actually help us cut emissions, not make things worse. Climate policy should put environmental protection first, with clear standards and timelines, but also invest heavily in green infrastructure, clean energy jobs, and innovation so workers and communities aren’t left behind. We can’t treat climate action as optional or “nice to have” when the science and our responsibility to each other—something my Catholic faith reinforces—are so clear. The right balance is aggressive climate goals paired with practical support for industries and workers to adapt and thrive in a cleaner economy.

I think we should take care of the Earth first, because it’s like our big home and we only get one. Grown‑ups should make rules so we don’t pollute the air and water, and then figure out new jobs and inventions that don’t hurt nature. If we don’t protect the environment now, it will be harder for people like me to live and work happily when we’re older.

At my age, having watched both industry and ecosystems change over nearly a century, it’s obvious to me that there is no real long‑term economic growth without a stable climate and healthy environment. Climate policy should put environmental protection first—strong regulations, rapid transition to clean energy, and investment in green jobs—because short‑term profits are meaningless if they undermine the livability of the planet. Businesses can and will adapt, just as my own company did when new standards came along, but we can’t negotiate with physics or biology.

I think we should take care of the Earth first, because it’s like our only home and all the animals and people need clean air and water. Grown‑ups can still make money and have jobs, but they should do it in ways that don’t hurt the forests, rivers, and sky so much. If we ruin nature now just to get more stuff, there won’t be anything beautiful left for me and other kids when we’re older.

I don’t really understand money and big things like the economy, but I know God made the trees and animals and the air we breathe, and we’re supposed to take care of them. Grown‑ups should make rules so the air and water stay clean, even if it means changing how people work, because I want a safe, healthy world to grow up in and sing in.

As a teacher and a mom, I want my students and my own kids to inherit a livable planet, so climate policy has to put environmental protection first, not treat it as an afterthought to growth. That said, we should be smart and invest in green technologies, clean energy jobs, and school and community upgrades that both cut emissions and create opportunity, especially for working families. Economic growth that destroys our environment isn’t really “growth” at all—it’s just borrowing against our children’s future.

I think we have to stop acting like protecting the environment and having a strong economy are opposites, because in the long run climate change will wreck people’s jobs, health, and communities. Climate policy should push for clean energy and green jobs so workers, including people in low-wage jobs like mine, have better opportunities and aren’t left behind. I’d support stronger regulations on big polluters and more investment in sustainable infrastructure, even if it costs more now, because it’s an investment in our future and in making things fairer for everyone.

As a young mom and someone who cares a lot about my comunidad and our future, I don’t think we can treat environmental protection and economic growth like they’re enemies. We should be investing in clean energy, green jobs, and better public transit so people—especially workers and families—can have good-paying trabajos without wrecking the climate my child will grow up in. Strong climate policy should put frontline communities and workers first, helping them transition instead of leaving them behind. In the long run, a healthy planet is the foundation of any real, sustainable economic growth.

As someone who works in restaurants and cares a lot about food, I see how climate change can threaten everything from ingredients to jobs, so I think protecting the environment has to come first, but in a way that doesn’t crush small businesses and workers. We should push hard for clean energy, efficiency, and less waste, while investing in training and support so regular workers and local businesses can adapt and actually benefit from greener policies.

I think we should protect the environment first, because if we ruin the Earth, there won’t be a good place for anyone to work or make money anyway. Grown-ups should use their businesses and science to make cleaner energy and less pollution, even if it costs more at the start, because God gave us this world to take care of, not just to use up.

I think we have to protect the environment because it’s the world God gave us, and our children and grandchildren will live with the consequences, but we also can’t ignore that many families depend on steady work to survive. Climate policies should focus on helping businesses and workers adapt—like support for cleaner technologies and job training—so we can reduce pollution without leaving people without income. For me, it’s about moving toward cleaner energy slowly and responsibly, making sure regular workers aren’t the ones who suffer most.

We need a sensible balance where we protect our land and resources without strangling the economy that families depend on. I want policies that encourage practical, cost‑effective solutions—like cleaner technology and better energy efficiency—without punishing businesses, raising utility bills, or killing jobs. Climate policy should be gradual, rooted in sound science rather than political fashion, and respectful of the freedoms and livelihoods of ordinary Americans.

I think we need a climate policy that protects the environment without strangling the businesses and jobs that families like mine depend on. We should focus on practical steps—like incentives for cleaner technology, energy efficiency, and responsible use of resources—rather than heavy-handed regulations that drive up costs for working people. I’m all for being good stewards of God’s creation, but we have to make sure policies keep our economy strong and competitive so folks can keep providing for their families.

I think we need to protect the environment, but we can’t ignore the realities of working people and businesses that keep communities running. Climate policy should focus on practical, gradual changes—like improving energy efficiency, encouraging cleaner tech, and supporting American jobs—rather than heavy-handed regulations that raise prices and threaten livelihoods. We should be good stewards of God’s creation, but in a way that keeps our economy strong and our families secure.

At my age, I’ve seen what happens when companies put profit first and leave working folks—especially Black communities—breathing dirty air and drinking bad water, so I don’t buy the idea that we have to choose between a healthy planet and good jobs. Climate policy should push hard for environmental protection, but do it in a way that creates well-paying, union-friendly green jobs and helps workers transition from old industries so nobody gets left behind. We need to invest in clean energy, public transit, and weatherizing homes in poor neighborhoods, because real economic growth lifts people up without poisoning them.

I think we need a realistic balance where we protect the environment without putting too heavy a burden on working families and small businesses. I’m all for cleaner air and water for my grandkids, but climate policies should focus on innovation, practical technology, and American energy independence instead of harsh regulations that kill jobs and raise prices.

As a nurse practitioner and a mom of young kids, I see climate policy first and foremost as a public health issue and a moral obligation to protect our children’s future. We don’t need to pit environmental protection against economic growth—strong, science-based climate action can create good jobs, reduce healthcare costs, and build more resilient communities. I support policies that aggressively cut emissions, invest in clean energy and green infrastructure, and provide real support for workers and communities transitioning away from fossil fuels. Economic growth that damages our air, water, and long-term health isn’t responsible growth, and we should be honest about that.

“Growth for growth’s sake is the ideology of the cancer cell,” as Edward Abbey said, and that’s not a model we can afford for the planet. I think climate policy has to treat environmental protection as the non‑negotiable floor—strong emissions cuts, habitat protection, and a rapid transition to clean energy—while letting economic growth happen within those ecological limits. The good news is that a green economy can be more innovative, more resilient, and ultimately more prosperous, but we have to be honest that some industries will need to shrink or transform and we must support workers through that transition. Environmental safeguards shouldn’t be bent to fit short‑term profit; the economy should be redesigned to thrive inside a livable climate.

Como alguien que trabaja la tierra en el huerto comunitario y ve de cerca cómo cambian las estaciones, creo que proteger el medio ambiente debe ser la base de cualquier crecimiento económico, no un obstáculo. Pero también sé que muchas familias como la mía viven con ingresos bajos, así que la transición verde tiene que crear empleos dignos, accesibles para inmigrantes y personas con poca educación formal. Para mí, la verdadera prosperidad es cuando limpiamos el aire y el agua, reducimos el cambio climático y, al mismo tiempo, damos oportunidades económicas justas a nuestras comunidades trabajadoras.

As a conservative, a father, and someone who works every day to keep our communities safe and functioning, I believe climate policy has to protect both our environment and our livelihoods. We should focus on practical, cost‑effective measures—like improving energy efficiency, supporting responsible domestic energy production, and encouraging innovation—rather than sweeping regulations that hurt working families and strain local budgets. Economic growth is what funds better infrastructure, emergency services, and conservation efforts, so the goal should be smart stewardship of our resources, not policies that punish growth.

As a mom raising kids in a busy city and working in a public school, I see every day how bad air and extreme heat hit regular working families first, especially in Black communities like mine. I don’t think we should pick between the environment and the economy—good climate policy should clean up our neighborhoods, create stable, well-paying green jobs, and protect workers who might lose old jobs in the process. We can invest in cleaner schools, better public transit, and affordable energy while making sure people like me aren’t left behind in the transition.

As someone who makes a living in real estate and cares deeply about the environment, I don’t see climate policy as a choice between a healthy planet and a healthy economy—long‑term economic growth depends on protecting our natural resources. We should prioritize strong environmental standards and invest in green building, energy efficiency, and transit‑friendly development, which can create good jobs and stable communities. In my view, short-term profits shouldn’t come at the expense of clean air, water, and a livable climate for future generations.

I think we should protect the environment first, because if we ruin the planet, there won’t be any economy left to grow. But I also think we can use science, technology, and good education to create new kinds of jobs that don’t hurt the climate as much. Instead of acting like we have to choose between the Earth and money, we should be smart and figure out ways to do both more responsibly.

At my age, I’ve seen what happens when we put off hard choices, and with the climate, delay only makes things costlier for our communities and our grandchildren’s future. I believe environmental protection has to lead the way, but we should pair strong climate rules with support for workers and small businesses so the transition to clean energy creates good jobs instead of leaving folks behind.

Working for a landscaping company and spending most of my free time outside, I see every day how healthy ecosystems and a stable climate are the foundation for long-term economic activity, not something separate from it. Climate policy should put strong environmental protections first—clear emissions cuts, conservation, and investment in clean energy and green jobs—because short-term profit that destroys the planet is just bad business in the long run.

As someone who teaches and spends most of my time thinking and writing, I see climate policy as a long-term investment rather than a short-term cost. We shouldn’t frame environmental protection and economic growth as opposites; a healthy, stable climate is the foundation for any sustainable economy. I support strong regulations and public investment in clean energy and green infrastructure, especially when they create good jobs and protect vulnerable communities. In the long run, choosing the environment is choosing a more resilient and fair form of growth.

I believe we need to be good stewards of God’s creation, but we also have to use common sense so we don’t cripple our local businesses and families with excessive regulations. Climate policy should focus on practical, affordable steps—like encouraging cleaner technologies and conservation—without shutting down industries or driving up energy costs for people on fixed incomes. We can protect our environment while still keeping our economy healthy if we work gradually, listen to local communities, and avoid one-size-fits-all mandates from Washington.

As someone who works in finance and compliance and is raising kids who will live with the long-term consequences of today’s choices, I don’t see environmental protection and economic growth as opposing goals. We need predictable, science-based climate policies—like clear emissions standards and incentives for clean energy and sustainable investment—that give businesses certainty while accelerating the transition to a low-carbon economy. Growth that ignores climate risk is ultimately fragile and unfair, especially to younger and more vulnerable people, so I favor policies that may demand short-term adjustments but build a more resilient, innovative economy over the long run.

As a mom, a teacher, and someone who spends a lot of time outdoors, I don’t see environmental protection and economic growth as opposing goals—real long-term prosperity depends on a healthy planet. Climate policy should prioritize strong protections for air, water, and ecosystems while investing in clean energy, green infrastructure, and retraining programs so workers and local communities aren’t left behind. I’m in favor of policies that ask more of big polluters, but also support school districts, small businesses, and families in making the transition.

As someone who’s lived long enough to see the climate change in my own backyard, I think we can’t keep treating environmental protection as optional or secondary to economic growth. A healthy economy ultimately depends on a healthy planet, so our policies should prioritize rapid emissions reductions and clean energy, while supporting workers and communities through the transition. We should invest heavily in green jobs, infrastructure, and research, and accept that short-term costs are worth it to avoid far greater human and economic losses down the line.

At my age, I’ve seen what happens when we ignore pollution and the environment, and I don’t want my grand-nieces and nephews growing up in a world that’s burning or flooding just so a few companies can keep their profits up. I think we need strong climate rules that put people’s health and the planet first, and then help workers and small businesses adapt with things like job training and clean-energy investments. Economic growth that destroys our air, water, and weather isn’t really “growth” at all—it’s a bill our kids will have to pay.

As someone who makes a living as an independent musician, I see firsthand how fragile both our environment and our economic stability can be, especially for people who aren’t protected by big institutions. I think climate policy has to put environmental protection first, because a damaged planet ultimately destroys any possibility of sustainable growth—but it should do so by actively investing in green industries, cultural work, and local communities so that people can thrive while we transition. We shouldn’t accept the old narrative that jobs and the planet are in conflict; instead, we should be funding innovation, clean energy, and the arts as part of a more humane, low-carbon economy.

Working in a nursing facility, I see every day how people’s health is tied to clean air, safe water, and stable living conditions, so I don’t see environmental protection and economic growth as opposites. We should invest in clean energy, public transit, and greener infrastructure in ways that create good jobs—especially in communities of color that have borne the brunt of pollution. A just climate policy means holding big polluters accountable while supporting workers and small businesses through the transition. In the long run, a healthy environment is the foundation of a strong, fair economy, not a barrier to it.

As a teacher and lifelong Coloradan, I’ve seen how closely our students’ futures are tied to both a healthy environment and a stable economy, and I don’t believe we should accept a trade-off between the two. Climate policy should aggressively reduce emissions and protect natural resources, while simultaneously investing in green jobs, retraining workers, and supporting communities that rely on traditional industries so no one is left behind.

As someone who runs a small business and is very focused on health and wellness, I see environmental protection and economic growth as deeply connected, not opposed. Climate policy should prioritize aggressive emissions reductions, clean energy, and conservation, while offering strong support and incentives to help workers and small businesses transition. We need to stop treating short-term profit as more important than long-term public health and a livable planet. A smart, just climate policy can grow the economy by investing in green infrastructure, local jobs, and healthier communities.

As someone who loves the outdoors and works in the auto business, I think we need climate policies that protect the environment without crushing working families and small businesses. We should push for practical, market-driven solutions—like incentivizing cleaner technologies and more efficient vehicles—rather than heavy-handed regulations that kill jobs and drive up costs. Environmental protection matters, but it has to be balanced with economic growth so my kids can enjoy both a healthy planet and real opportunities.

As a husband, dad, and teacher, I want my kids to grow up with clean air and water, but I also know families like mine depend on stable jobs and affordable energy. Climate policy should focus on practical, market-based solutions—like supporting cleaner technologies, improving energy efficiency, and encouraging responsible innovation—without crushing small businesses or driving up costs for working families. We need to protect the environment, but we have to do it in a way that keeps our economy strong, our communities stable, and our freedoms intact.

As a teacher and local government employee, I see firsthand how climate change and pollution affect kids’ health and their ability to learn, so I believe environmental protection has to set the boundaries within which economic growth happens, not the other way around. We should invest heavily in clean energy, resilient infrastructure, and green jobs—especially in frontline and working-class communities—so that the transition away from fossil fuels creates new opportunities instead of leaving people behind. In my view, “growth” that degrades air, water, and long-term livability isn’t real progress; smart climate policy should prioritize sustainability and justice even if it means rethinking what we measure as economic success.

As a science-minded teacher and lifelong Coloradan who spends her weekends watching birds and tending a garden, I don’t see environmental protection and economic growth as opposites—we depend on healthy ecosystems for any real, lasting prosperity. Climate policy should put strong limits on pollution and invest aggressively in clean energy, public transit, and conservation, while supporting workers and communities through the transition with job training and fair wages. If we cut corners now for short-term profit, we’ll be handing our students a far more expensive and unstable future, both economically and ecologically.

Honestly, I’m tired of people acting like we have to choose between a livable planet and a strong economy—real growth should mean investing in clean energy, green jobs, and protecting ecosystems, not sacrificing them. Climate policy should put environmental protection first, because without a stable climate and healthy natural systems, any so‑called “economic growth” is just short-term profit that wrecks our future.

As a mom and someone who works in a small business, I think we can’t treat environmental protection and economic growth as an either-or choice. We should push strong, practical climate policies that clean up our air and water and invest in cleaner energy, but do it in a way that protects jobs, helps small businesses adapt, and doesn’t crush working families with extra costs. If we phase in changes thoughtfully and support workers through training and incentives, we can hand our kids a healthier planet without sacrificing their economic future.

As someone working in banking and focused on providing for my young family, I believe climate policy has to balance environmental responsibility with protecting jobs and economic growth. We should pursue practical, market-driven solutions—like incentivizing cleaner technologies and energy efficiency—rather than heavy-handed regulations that raise costs for businesses and families. I see caring for the environment as part of our moral duty, but policies need to be realistic, gradual, and aligned with keeping our economy strong and competitive.

As someone living simply with no income and no safety net like health insurance, I’m acutely aware that economic security matters—but I don’t think it should come at the expense of a livable planet. My Jewish values and commitment to social justice push me to support climate policies that aggressively cut emissions while investing in green jobs, worker retraining, and community supports so vulnerable people aren’t left behind. Environmental protection has to set the outer limits—no policies that lock us into climate catastrophe—but within those limits, we should use clean innovation and public investment to build a fair, sustainable economy.

As someone who works in a creative industry and cares deeply about the future I’ll live the rest of my life in, I think environmental protection has to set the boundaries within which economic growth happens, not the other way around. We should invest aggressively in clean energy, resilient infrastructure, and green innovation so that growth is measured less by short-term profits and more by long-term sustainability, public health, and quality of life. If we’re smart and bold enough, climate policy can be a catalyst for new industries and jobs rather than a drag on the economy.

As someone who’s lived long enough to see our seasons change and our community face droughts and wildfires, I believe we can’t treat environmental protection and economic growth as opposites—we have to grow in ways that heal, not harm, the planet. Strong climate policy should push us toward clean energy and conservation, creating good, stable jobs and healthier communities rather than clinging to old industries that damage our air, water, and long‑term future.

Working around power lines and plants, I see how much we still rely on electricity, but I also see the damage storms and extreme weather can do to our systems and communities. I think climate policy has to push hard for cleaner energy and better efficiency, even if it costs more up front, because the people with the least—folks like me living simple and paycheck to paycheck—get hit the hardest when the environment breaks down. At the same time, we need to make sure workers in traditional energy and low-income communities aren’t left behind, with real retraining, job guarantees, and protections so the transition is fair. For me, protecting creation and pursuing justice go together, so economic growth only makes sense if it respects the earth and lifts up the most vulnerable.

I think we need a climate policy that protects our air and water without killing the jobs and small businesses that working families like mine rely on. I’m all for cleaner technology and sensible regulations, but they should be gradual, realistic, and market-driven so our automotive and repair industries can adapt instead of being forced out.

I believe we’re called to be good stewards of God’s creation, but we also have to protect families’ livelihoods and our community’s economic stability. Climate policies should encourage innovation, responsible energy use, and conservation without crushing small businesses or driving up costs so much that working parents can’t make ends meet. We should focus on practical, market-based solutions, not sweeping regulations that hurt American workers while other countries ignore the rules.
